## FDA Software Validation and Remediation Requirements

### Key FDA Guidance Documents

The FDA has established general validation principles applicable to the validation of medical device software or the validation of software used to design, develop, or manufacture medical devices.

### Regulatory Requirements

Under 21 CFR Â§820.30, any medical device software product developed after June 1, 1997, regardless of its device class, is subject to applicable design control provisions. Design controls such as planning, input, verification, and reviews are required for medical device software.(no content)21 CFR Â§820.70(i) requires that any software used to automate any part of the device production process or any part of the quality system must be validated for its intended use. This requirement applies to any software used to automate device design, testing, component acceptance, manufacturing, labeling, packaging, distribution, complaint handling, or to automate any other aspect of the quality system.

### Remediation Planning

Key questions for remediation include: How do I determine which systems require remediation? What are the planning issues for a remediation project? Remediation project planning guidelines should address these concerns.(no content)Remediation aims to bring a system, process, or product back into compliance before serious consequences such as fines, criminal charges, import bans, or poor reputation can occur.(no content)Once the non-conformities and their causes have been fully identified and understood, the next step is to plan the remediation. The plan should include: planned corrections and corrective and preventive actions and the associated changes to the QM system including processes and procedures. Companies should communicate their plan to the notified body or authority.

### Validation Plan Requirements

There are five steps to FDA software validation. Step 1: Create a validation plan that documents various aspects of the software system, its installed environment and project limitations. The plan will also include the testing and acceptance criteria, development procedures and responsibilities of the members of the validation team.(no content)A Master Validation Plan outlines the scope of the validation project and the strategy for validating the software's installation and use. It includes an overview of each process, the validation approach and the rationale for following it. Design Qualification (DQ) identifies key functionality, design specifications and software requirements. Risk Assessment and Management documents the risk factors and mitigations associated with using the software to produce regulated goods.

### Response to FDA Inspections

The FDA documents deviations ("inspectional observations") on a form with the number 483. In case of major violations, a warning letter can be issued.(no content)Remediation activities include understanding the non-conformity reports and regulatory requirements (including the scope for implementation), communication with the authority or notified body (e.g., drafting an appropriate response to a warning letter), root cause analysis and development of an action plan, and support with the implementation of actions (e.g., establishing a new procedure, validation of processes).

### Modern Approaches - Computer Software Assurance (CSA)

In 2022, the FDA introduced the concept of Computer Software Assurance (CSA). This approach shifts the focus from compliance-centric activities to critical thinking and risk-based decision-making. CSA encourages leveraging automated tools, real-world evidence, and agile practices to streamline validation processes. By reducing unnecessary documentation and emphasizing testing where it matters most, CSA aims to promote innovation and efficiency without compromising quality or patient safety.

## Fagan Inspection Methodology in the Context of FDA-Regulated Software

### What is Fagan Inspection?

A Fagan inspection is a process of trying to find defects in documents (such as source code or formal specifications) during various phases of the software development process. It is named after Michael Fagan, who is credited with the invention of formal software inspections.(no content)The definition of Software Inspection was proposed by Michael Fagan in 1976 when he worked at IBM and performed seminal work about Experimental Software Engineering using peer-meeting code review. In that work, a team was organized in a meeting with a formal protocol to detect defects.

### Key Characteristics of Fagan Inspection

Fagan inspection is a widely applicable, rigorous and formal software engineering QC technique for inspection of any document when it is believed complete and ready for use. It finds defects directly â€“ unlike testing, which happens later, and only reveals symptoms.(no content)According to this method, inspection must be formal; materials to be inspected must be prepared and meet the inspection entry criteria; and people who inspect must be qualified, as well as the time and place must be arranged ahead of time. There are formal roles for each participant and they must be trained in the method.

### The Fagan Inspection Process Stages

The stages in the inspections process are: Planning, Overview meeting, Preparation, Inspection meeting, Rework and Follow-up.(no content)Planning: The inspection is planned by the moderator. Overview meeting: The author describes the background of the work product. Preparation: Each inspector examines the work product to identify possible defects. Inspection meeting: During this meeting the reader reads through the work product, part by part and the inspectors point out the defects for every part. Rework: The author makes changes to the work product according to the action plans from the inspection meeting.

### Entry and Exit Criteria

For Fagan inspections the high- and low-level documents must comply with specific entry criteria before they can be used for a formal inspection process. Exit criteria are the criteria or requirements which must be met to complete a specific process. For Fagan inspections the low-level document must comply with specific exit criteria before the development process can be taken to the next phase.

### Connection to FDA-Regulated Software

The FDA's guidance on software validation for medical devices mentions the use of formal inspection methods. The FDA discusses dynamic analyses, code and document inspections, walkthroughs, and other techniques as part of software validation activities.(no content)For purposes of this guidance, FDA considers software validation to be "confirmation by examination and provision of objective evidence that software specifications conform to user needs and intended uses, and that the particular requirements implemented through software can be consistently fulfilled."(no content)Planning, verification, testing, traceability, configuration management, and many other aspects of good software engineering discussed in this guidance are important activities that together help to support a final conclusion that software is validated.

### Effectiveness and Benefits

Since introducing the inspection process in 1974, IBM achieved significant improvements in quality. The company nearly doubled the number of lines of code shipped for System/370 software products since 1976, while the number of defects per thousand lines of code was reduced by two-thirds.(no content)The inspection is the most formal of the three validation and verification techniques (reviews, walkthroughs, inspections) and is based on Fagan's concepts of a disciplined process to detect defects.(no content)Fagan inspection is the most cited inspection method in the literature and is the basis upon which all the other methods are designed.

## Defect Tracking and CAPA Integration for FDA-Regulated Medical Device Software

### Regulatory Framework

CAPA requirements for medical device companies are established through standards and regulations, including ISO 13485:2016, FDA 21 CFR 820, EU MDR, and EU IVDR.(no content)These requirements mandate a structured approach to identifying, investigating, correcting, and preventing recorded issues, ensuring compliance with global regulatory expectations.(no content)The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the European Medicines Agency (EMA), and the European Union (EU) all require a CAPA system to be put in place to determine and mitigate risks that can prevent adverse events and product failures.

### Defect Classification and Severity Levels

Based on the nature of business and operations, teams can measure the number of deviations that occurred, the nature and severity of the deviations following the solution being implemented, and the impact of the new process on the specific product.(no content)CAPA application should be sensible and risk-based - there's no point throwing all your resources at a minor defect when there's a major fire to fight. Link your CAPAs to the severity, impact on quality, and potential risks of the issues they're addressing. This allows you to allocate resources tactically and address critical issues with the highest priority.

### CAPA Process Integration

The CAPA process for medical device companies involves several structured steps. First, the issue is identified based on complaints, audit findings, or quality control data. Second, the issue is evaluated and prioritized based on its potential impact, followed by developing an initial CAPA plan. A root cause analysis (RCA) is conducted to determine underlying causes. CAPA actions are then created and implemented, and their effectiveness is verified before formally closing the CAPA. Continuous review and trend analysis help with overall continuous improvement.(no content)Integration with QMS is essential - integrate CAPA with your overall Quality Management System (QMS) to ensure consistency across processes and regulatory compliance.

### Key Data Sources for Defect Tracking

Data collection involves gathering relevant data (e.g., defect rates, complaint records, failure modes) to understand the problem's scope and impact.(no content)Typically, consumer complaints are one of the biggest indicators of problems with distributed products, and as a result, CAPA processes. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has underlined this point, stating that it views complaints as a more important CAPA data source.

### Root Cause Analysis Tools

Investigations should conduct a thorough investigation to determine the underlying cause(s) of the issue (e.g., manufacturing defects, design flaws, or process problems). Techniques include problem-solving tools like 5 Whys, Fishbone (Ishikawa) Diagram, Failure Mode and Effect Analysis (FMEA), or Fault Tree Analysis (FTA) to identify root causes.

### FDA Inspection Focus

CAPA process definition is a huge issue for medical device companies. This issue is the single biggest reason FDA issues 483 observations to medical device companies year after year since 2010.(no content)The FDA issued over 700 inspectional observations related to CAPA deficiencies in a single year.

### Software-Specific Requirements

Software must be developed in accordance with the requirements of the Quality System Regulation (QS regulation) (21 CFR part 820).(no content)For software contained in medical devices, manufacturers should describe all outstanding anomalies or software defects with corresponding workarounds, where applicable, if these issues are not addressed in the User's Manual.

### Documentation and Compliance

CAPA Records must document all actions taken, from problem identification to root cause analysis and corrective/preventive actions. Include supporting evidence, investigation results, and verification outcomes. Ensure that CAPA documentation complies with relevant standards, such as ISO 13485 or FDA 21 CFR Part 820. Maintain these records for audits or inspections.

## FDA Requirements for Software Validation and Documentation

### Traceability Requirements

FDA requires conformance to all software specifications and confirmation that all software requirements are traceable to system specifications. Validation of software typically includes evidence that all software requirements have been implemented correctly and completely and are traceable to system requirements.(no content)The traceability analysis aims to ensure that all requirements for the FDA compliance software system are properly tested during the test protocols. This document serves as a tool for both the validation team and auditors. This process should be performed using a Requirement Traceability Matrix (RTM), which allows developers to measure test coverage and map system requirements and change requests.

### Software Verification and Code Review Evidence

Software verification provides objective evidence that the design outputs of a particular phase of the software development life cycle meet all of the specified requirements for that phase. Software verification looks for consistency, completeness, and correctness of the software and its supporting documentation. Software testing is one of many verification activities, along with various static and dynamic analyses, code and document inspections, and walkthroughs.(no content)The FDA rules state that all software changes need verification before approval and use. Teams must document all verification activities and results properly.

### Audit Trail Requirements

A cornerstone of compliance trust is the audit trail â€“ the record of who did what, when, and why to an electronic record. Both the FDA in its 21 CFR Part 11 rules and the EU GMP Annex 11 guidelines explicitly require robust audit trails for computerized systems. These audit trails enable transparency and traceability of all changes to GxP-critical data.(no content)Audit trails provide transparency and accountability, as any unauthorized change, deletion, or fabrication of data is expected to be evident in the audit log. FDA investigators explicitly look for audit trails during inspections, and a missing or incomplete audit trail is a red flag for data integrity issues.

### 21 CFR Part 11 Compliance

21 CFR Part 11 sets expectations for how companies must design, operate, and uphold computer systems that store regulated information. It covers topics like access controls, audit trails, validation, and electronic signature management.(no content)Compliance with 21 CFR Part 11 is not only about the technology used. It is also about the procedures, training, and controls that support how people interact with that technology. Regulators expect companies to show that their systems are trustworthy, that their processes are well defined, and that their staff understand and follow those processes consistently.

### Documentation Requirements

Proper documentation is essential in the FDA validation process. Every step of validation, from planning to ongoing monitoring, must be carefully documented to establish an audit trail that proves compliance. Documentation should also demonstrate that the validation activities were comprehensive and followed FDA guidelines.(no content)Validation protocols, test records, risk assessments, and compliance documents should be organized in a centralized manner. This helps ensure that evidence required for FDA audits and submissions is accurate, accessible, and up to date.

### Data Integrity Requirements

FDA expects that all data be reliable and accurate. CGMP regulations and guidance allow for flexible and risk-based strategies to prevent and detect data integrity issues. Firms should implement meaningful and effective strategies to manage their data integrity risks based on their process understanding and knowledge management of technologies.(no content)Data should be maintained throughout the record's retention period with all associated metadata required to reconstruct the CGMP activity. The relationships between data and their metadata should be preserved in a secure and traceable manner.

### Best Practices

Following a risk-based validation approach (as advocated by ISPE's GAMPÂ®5 and FDA's CSA guidance) is beneficial â€“ focus validation efforts on functions that impact product quality and data integrity, including audit trail recording. The validation should also test boundary cases. All such tests and their results must be documented, forming evidence for inspectors that the audit trail works as intended.(no content)Bug reporting and the linkage of bugs to test cases must be completely traceable.

Here are the key findings on **21 CFR Part 11 audit trail requirements and change control procedures**:

## Key Regulatory Requirements

### Audit Trail Requirements (21 CFR 11.10(e))

"Revision and change control procedures to maintain an audit trail that documents time-sequenced development and modification of systems documentation."(no content)Record changes shall not obscure previously recorded information. Such audit trail documentation shall be retained for a period at least as long as that required for the subject electronic records and shall be available for agency review and copying.

### Core Audit Trail Components

Compliance with 21 CFR Part 11 requires maintaining secure, computer-generated audit trails that document all modifications to electronic records. These trails support data integrity by recording what changes were made, who made them, and when.(no content)User actions and system events must be recorded with a precise timestamp, including date and time. The timestamp should be based on a reliable and synchronized clock, typically a central server time.(no content)The audit trail must capture sufficient detail about each action, including the specific type of action, the data element affected, and the previous and new values of any changed data.

### Automatic Generation Requirement

As outlined in 21 CFR 11.10(e), an audit trail must be automatically generated by the system and not manually created to eliminate human errors.

## Change Control Procedures

Change control processes ensure that system changes are properly evaluated, approved, and documented before implementation. This prevents unauthorized modifications that could compromise data integrity.(no content)A formal change control process should be in place for system updates, configuration adjustments, or workflow changes. Each modification must be reviewed for its potential impact on compliance before being implemented.

## Additional Controls Required

Authority checks must ensure that only authorized individuals can use the system, electronically sign a record, access the operation or computer system input or output device, alter a record, or perform the operation at hand.(no content)Persons who develop, maintain, or use electronic record/electronic signature systems must have the education, training, and experience to perform their assigned tasks.

## FDA Enforcement Discretion

The FDA has noted concerns that some interpretations of Part 11 requirements would unnecessarily restrict electronic technology use. These concerns have been raised particularly in the areas of Part 11 requirements for validation, audit trails, record retention, record copying, and legacy systems.

## FDA Warning Letters & Software Validation: Medical Device Case Studies (2023-2024)

### Key Statistics

The 2024 fiscal year (October 2023 - September 2024) saw 47 warning letters issued to medical device companies, representing a 96% increase from the 24 letters issued in 2023.(no content)The U.S. FDA Center for Devices and Radiological Health (CDRH) issued 567 warning letters in 2023, most related to drugs, tobacco products or food products. Of those, 4% of all warning letters (24) were issued for medical devices.(no content)The FDA's Center for Devices and Radiological Health (CDRH) issued 529 warning letters in 2024, most related to drugs, tobacco products or food products. Of those, 8% (44) were issued for medical devices.

### Notable Case Studies

**iRhythm Technologies (2023)**
Between May 25, 2023, the date of the FDA warning letter to iRhythm, and June 27th, iRhythm stock fell almost 25%.(no content)The threat an FDA warning letter poses to any company is significant and existential to a startup. The immediate consequence is the disruption and resource diversion to rectify issues, instantly detracting from R&D and growth.

**Small Company Scrutiny**
The FDA is now auditing and issuing warning letters to small companies. Recent letters sent to Vitang (4 people) and ZYTO (56 people) underscore the FDA's growing scrutiny on the proliferation of medical device startups and their software validation processes.

### Top Deficiency Categories

First place is taken by deficiencies relating to "Design Controls" (21 CFR 820.30) and "CAPA (21 CFR 211.100)". Second place is shared by deficiencies relating to process validation (21 CFR 820.75) and "Complaints" (21 CFR 820.198). In third place are deficiencies relating to "Purchasing Controls" (21 CFR 820.50).

### Software-Specific Concerns

The FDA is scrutinizing multiple areas including: Product Software validation â€“ Not validating or verifying medical device software properly; Non-software product validation â€“ Not validating or verifying infrastructure software (GxP software) used in manufacturing; Procedure coverage and deviation â€“ Not having procedures required by FDA 21 CFR Part 820 or Part 11 quality regulations.(no content)Risk management was a major topic of discussion related back to many of the violations this year, and was mentioned in many of the warning letters, including for the initial validation of device design and noting that risk management was not updated either in alignment with the procedure or alignment with ISO 14971 when compliance with the standard was claimed.

### Regulatory Shift

The FDA has moved away from the "integrative approach" where companies could resolve issues through response letters to 483 observations. Instead, the agency is issuing warning letters more readily when companies fail to address FDA 483 observations and warning letters.(no content)The escalation from 483 observations to warning letters typically occurs when companies provide inadequate responses or fail to implement effective corrective actions within reasonable timeframes.

### Recommendations for Prevention

Key preventive measures include: Strengthen quality systems - Robust CAPA, design controls, and complaint handling prevent violations; Prepare for inspections - Regular mock inspections and staff training improve readiness; Leverage technology - Modern quality management systems enable efficient compliance; Build compliance culture - Sustainable prevention requires organization-wide commitment.

Here are the search results for IEC 62304 software safety classification, code review, testing, and verification:

## IEC 62304 Overview

IEC 62304 â€“ medical device software â€“ software life cycle processes is an international standard published by the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC). The standard specifies life cycle requirements for the development of medical software and software within medical devices.

## Software Safety Classifications

IEC 62304 identifies three safety classes for medical device software:
- **Class A**: No injury or damage to health is possible
- **Class B**: Injury is possible, but not serious
- **Class C**: Death or serious injury is possible(no content)The number of activities you need to complete according to the standard depend on how harmful your medical device is. This is decided with a software safety classification â€“ the higher risks and severity linked to your software, the higher classification.

## Code Review and Verification Requirements

It's required to establish tests for software requirements for Class B and Class C. You can fulfill this requirement by using an ALM tool to generate test cases based on requirements and create a requirements traceability matrix.(no content)Class B and Class C software also need to establish a software unit verification process. You can fulfill this requirement by using a static code analyzer to verify code against a coding standard and ensure safe, secure, and reliable software.(no content)Static code analysis tools identify violations of coding guidelines and standards at an early stage. They also detect clones, cycles or unreachable code to ensure the quality of your software.

## Testing Requirements

Testing activities outlined in IEC 62304 require requirements-based testing, functional testing, and risk-based testing.(no content)The IEC 62304 standard calls out certain cautions on using software, particularly SOUP (software of unknown pedigree or provenance). The standard spells out a risk-based decision model on when the use of SOUP is acceptable, and defines testing requirements for SOUP.

## Documentation Requirements by Safety Class

The software safety class determines specific requirements for each step in the software development process. For software in safety class A, manufacturers only need to document the software requirements (5.2) and software release (5.8). For class B, the software architecture (5.3) and software verification (5.5 to 5.7) must also be documented, and for safety class C, the detailed design (5.4) must also be documented.

## Standard Structure

IEC 62304 for medical device software development delineates components into five clauses, numbered 5 through 9:
- Clause 5: Outlines the software development process from planning to release
- Clause 6: Describes required maintenance of released software
- Clause 7: Specifies risk management required from assessing failures to identifying potential risks
- Clause 8: Lays out configuration management requirements
- Clause 9: Explains problem resolution processes(no content)The best approach to medical device software development is risk-based, structured and methodical. Traceability throughout the lifecycle of medical device software is key to ensure compliance with IEC 62304.

Based on my search results, I can now provide you with comprehensive information about the FDA's "General Principles of Software Validation" guidance from 2002 and its requirements regarding code review documentation.

## FDA General Principles of Software Validation (2002) - Code Review Documentation Requirements

### Overview of the Guidance

The "General Principles of Software Validation" was published by the FDA in 2002.(no content)This document provides guidance to medical device manufacturers and FDA staff concerning requirements for validating software used within medical devices, in device production, or in implementing the manufacturer's quality system.(no content)This guidance outlines general validation principles that the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) considers to be applicable to the validation of medical device software or the validation of software used to design, develop, or manufacture medical devices.

### Verification Activities Including Code Review

Software testing is one of many verification activities intended to confirm that software development output meets its input requirements. Other verification activities include various static and dynamic analyses, code and document inspections, walkthroughs, and other techniques.

### Source Code Evaluation and Static Analysis Requirements

Source code evaluations are often implemented as code inspections and code walkthroughs. Such static analyses provide a very effective means to detect errors before execution of the code. They allow for examination of each error in isolation and can also help in focusing later dynamic testing of the software.(no content)Firms may use manual (desk) checking with appropriate controls to ensure consistency and independence. Source code evaluations should be extended to verification of internal linkages between modules and layers (horizontal and vertical interfaces), and compliance with their design specifications.

### Documentation Requirements for Code Reviews

Documentation of the procedures used and the results of source code evaluations should be maintained as part of design verification. A source code traceability analysis is an important tool to verify that all code is linked to established specifications and established test procedures.(no content)FDA investigators will expect to see a verification procedure that includes a means for identifying and resolving incomplete, ambiguous, and conflicting requirements, as required by the regulation. They will also expect to see objective documented evidence that the verification procedure was implemented.

### Configuration Control and Documentation

Controls are necessary to ensure positive and correct correspondence among all approved versions of the specifications documents, source code, object code, and test suites that comprise a software system. The controls also should ensure accurate identification of, and access to, the currently approved versions.(no content)Procedures should be created for reporting and resolving software anomalies found through validation or other activities. Management should identify the reports and specify the contents, format, and responsible organizational elements for each report. Procedures also are necessary for the review and approval of software development results, including the responsible organizational elements for such reviews and approvals.

### Independent Evaluation

"Self-validation is extremely difficult. When possible, an independent evaluation is always better, especially for higher risk applications."

### Risk-Based Approach to Validation Coverage

Validation coverage should be based on the software's complexity and safety risk â€“ not on firm size or resource constraints. The selection of validation activities, tasks, and work items should be commensurate with the complexity of the software design and the risk associated with the use of the software for the specified intended use. For lower risk devices, only baseline validation activities may be conducted. As the risk increases additional validation activities should be added to cover the additional risk.

### Key Principles

The guidance emphasizes that "Software quality assurance needs to focus on preventing the introduction of defects into the software development process and not on trying to test quality into the software code after it is written."

## Overview of GAMP 5

GAMP â€” or the Good Automated Manufacturing Practice â€” is the definitive industry guideline for creating compliant computer systems.(no content)GAMP 5 provides a comprehensive framework for validating computerized systems to ensure they are fit for intended use and meet regulatory requirements. GAMP 5 is not a law or regulation itself, but an industry guidance published by the International Society for Pharmaceutical Engineering (ISPE) that has become the de facto standard for computer system validation in pharma.

## Code Review Requirements

For Category 5 (custom) software, testing requires rigorous supplier checks, code review, and unit tests. Examples include internally and externally developed IT applications, process controlled applications, customer ladder logic, custom firmware, ERP systems or developments made to meet specific needs for an organization.(no content)Key validation documentation includes source code review forms, software release forms, computer system validation policy, master validation plan, installation qualification, and operational qualification.

## Validation Lifecycle (V-Model)

GAMP 5 follows a structured development and validation lifecycle, often depicted as a "V-model". This covers stages from concept and requirements definition through design, testing, operation, and retirement. Each stage has associated deliverables and reviews.(no content)Systems must have clear User Requirements Specifications (URS). Testing verifies that the system meets these user and functional requirements (URS and FDS â€“ Functional Design Spec) before moving to production.

## Software Categories

Systems are classified into software/hardware categories (for example: Category 1 â€“ infrastructure, Category 3 â€“ non-configurable, Category 4 â€“ configurable, Category 5 â€“ custom). Higher categories (more customization) require more validation.

## Risk-Based Approach

This risk-based view is explicit in the GAMP 5 motto: it is formally titled "GAMPÂ® 5: A Risk-Based Approach to Compliant GxP Computerized Systems".(no content)Higher-risk systems (e.g., custom code controlling product quality) warrant more rigorous testing and documentation, whereas low-risk infrastructure software may need only basic verification.

## Key Validation Requirements

GAMP 5 recommends conducting periodic reviews to meet user requirements and regulatory standards. Revisit validation documentation whenever the software changes, use automation to analyze software end-to-end and track modifications. Make risk assessment a core part of your reviews and monitor the software's impact on safety and data protection.(no content)QAU review is essential to the success of the validation project. A customer's quality department's engagement in the development, review, and approvals of the validation steps and documentation determines the effectiveness of validation.

## GAMP 5 Second Edition Updates

The Second Edition promotes the use of automated traceability, tool-based reviews, and digital documentation systems, which reduce manual errors and improve data integrity.(no content)Embracing agile software development practices allows for iterative testing and continuous feedback. The guide explicitly supports non-linear development models and encourages validation activities throughout the lifecycle rather than at the end.(no content)Validation strategies must consider the provenance of the code, community support, update frequency, and compatibility with GxP requirements.

## FDA 483 and Warning Letters Overview

The FDA Form 483 is issued at the end of an on-site inspection if the FDA field investigator observed deficiencies in your quality system or conditions that violate the Food, Drug, or Cosmetic Act.(no content)The field inspector will submit the final 483 to superiors; if the findings are serious enough, or if the response is deemed insufficient, an FDA Warning Letter may be issued. A Warning Letter is the FDA's advisory notice that you have significantly violated FDA regulations.

## Software Validation Deficiencies

A third of recent warning letters included citations with respect to improper or ineffective validation. Computerized quality system tracking systems are subject to increased scrutiny during compliance and enforcement actions and hence incomplete software validations are ticking time bombs.(no content)FDA inspectors are now being trained to evaluate software validation practices. Increasing use of automated manufacturing and quality systems have increased exposure. Most recalls can be traced back to computerized equipment, exposing the validation process to scrutiny.

### Common Software-Related Findings

Common findings include software that was not validated and lacked audit trails, as well as firms lacking adequate controls to ensure that actions are attributed to authorized individuals with unique and unshared login credentials.(no content)The FDA will issue a Form 483 for noncompliance in the software validation GxP environment, mostly due to data integrity failures, inadequate written procedures, deficiencies in investigations, and substandard laboratory controls.

## Common FDA 483 Observation Categories

Common reasons for FDA 483 observations include: inadequate sanitation and cleaning logs, poor manufacturing documentation, lack of traceability and ingredient tracking, incorrect or misleading labeling, failure to monitor and validate processes, employee training deficiencies, supplier compliance issues, inadequate corrective and preventive actions, poor environmental controls, and lack of internal audits.(no content)The failure to establish, maintain, or follow a quality system remains one of the most cited issues during FDA inspections. For instance, a medical device manufacturer faced significant scrutiny for failing to document design reviews for a new surgical instrument. Similarly, a pharmaceutical company's inadequate training records for staff in quality oversight roles led to critical deviations.

## Major Deficiencies for Medical Devices

Major deficiencies relative to 21 CFR Part 820, the Quality System Regulation include absence of corrective and preventive action procedures (including procedures describing the analysis of quality data), absence of design control procedures (including design change control procedures), failure to validate processes requiring validation, non-correction or inadequate correction of major deficiencies from previous inspections, and other quality system deficiencies such as deficiencies in both purchasing controls and acceptance activities.

## Prevention Strategies

The best way to minimize your chances of receiving a Form 483 is to always be "inspection ready." Your quality management system should comply with US FDA 21 CFR Part 820 (Quality System Regulation) at all times because the FDA conducts random QSR audits with very little notice. Conduct regular internal audits of your QMS.(no content)Regular internal audits, enhanced training programs tailored to GMP and QSR requirements, and adopting advanced technologies such as electronic batch records and real-time monitoring systems can significantly reduce risks.

results:
Based on the search results, here is an overview of 21 CFR Part 11 electronic records, electronic signatures, code review requirements, and validation:

## 21 CFR Part 11 Overview

Part 11 defines the criteria under which electronic records and electronic signatures are considered trustworthy, reliable, and equivalent to paper records.(no content)Title 21 CFR Part 11 establishes the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulations on electronic records and electronic signatures, and is a portion of Title 21 of the Code of Federal Regulations.

## Validation Requirements

Computer systems used to create, modify, and maintain electronic records and to manage electronic signatures are subject to the validation requirements (See 21 CFR Â§11.10(a)). Such computer systems must be validated to ensure accuracy, reliability, consistent intended performance, and the ability to discern invalid or altered records.(no content)The FDA intends to exercise enforcement discretion regarding specific Part 11 requirements for validation of computerized systems (Â§ 11.10(a) and corresponding requirements in Â§ 11.30). Although persons must still comply with all applicable predicate rule requirements for validation (e.g., 21 CFR 820.70(i)), this guidance should not be read to impose any additional requirements for validation.(no content)The FDA suggests that your decision to validate computerized systems, and the extent of the validation, take into account the impact the systems have on your ability to meet predicate rule requirements. You should also consider the impact those systems might have on the accuracy, reliability, integrity, availability, and authenticity of required records and signatures. Even if there is no predicate rule requirement to validate a system, in some instances it may still be important to validate the system.

## Systems Documentation and Change Control

The regulation requires use of appropriate controls over systems documentation including: (1) Adequate controls over the distribution of, access to, and use of documentation for system operation and maintenance. (2) Revision and change control procedures to maintain an audit trail that documents time-sequenced development and modification of systems documentation.

## Electronic Signature Requirements

Electronic signatures that are not based upon biometrics shall employ at least two distinct identification components such as an identification code and password. When an individual executes a series of signings during a single, continuous period of controlled system access, the first signing shall be executed using all electronic signature components; subsequent signings shall be executed using at least one component that is only executable by the individual. When an individual executes one or more signings not performed during a single, continuous period of controlled system access, each signing shall be executed using all of the electronic signature components.(no content)Each electronic signature must be unique to one individual and not reused by, or reassigned to, anyone else. The identity of the individual must be verified before establishing, assigning, certifying or otherwise sanctioning the individual's electronic signature.

## Personnel Requirements

The regulation requires determination that persons who develop, maintain, or use electronic record/electronic signature systems have the education, training, and experience to perform their assigned tasks.(no content)Additionally, there must be establishment of, and adherence to, written policies that hold individuals accountable and responsible for actions initiated under their electronic signatures, in order to deter record and signature falsification.

## Technical and Procedural Controls

Compliance rests on both technical controls (software features like audit trails, access controls, and signature standards) and procedural controls (internal policies, SOPs, and employee training).(no content)To reach compliance, methods are developed and activities conducted for system validation, record generation, audit trails, operational and security controls, digital signatures and training. These methods and activities must be maintained through change control and management procedures to retain a compliant status.

Based on my search, here's comprehensive information on code review checklists and FDA compliance requirements for medical device software under IEC 62304:

## Overview of IEC 62304 and FDA Compliance for Medical Device Software

IEC 62304 is an international standard for medical device software that defines the framework for processes that occur across the lifecycle of the device and software.(no content)The IEC 62304 standard is harmonized internationally and is recognized by the FDA, Health Canada, the European Commission and other regulatory authorities worldwide.(no content)In the United States, the FDA accepts ANSI/AAMI/IEC 62304 as evidence that medical device software has been designed to an acceptable standard and covers regulatory processes such as 510(k), IDE, PMA, HDE, and Software Validation.

## Software Safety Classification

IEC 62304 identifies three classification categories for medical device software: Class A: No injury or damage to health is possible. Class B: Injury is possible, but not serious. Class C: Death or serious injury is possible.(no content)Classification impacts the entire software code development process in terms of what is required for compliance. This makes it critical to get right the first time around.

## Key Deliverables for IEC 62304 Compliance

### Software Development Plan
Software development plan - Define processes, deliverables, and development activities. The plan should include the Life Cycle Activities, Risk Management Plan, Documentation Plan, Configuration Management Plan, Change Control process, and Problem Resolution process.

### Software Verification Plan
Software verification plan - Describe the software test plan. Include all verification activities, such as code review, unit test and integration test plans, and the final system software verification test plan.

### Code Unit Verification
Code Unit Verification - Document the unit test and code review performed per the plan.

### Traceability
Summary test report - Create a summary of all software verification per the verification and validation plan. Trace matrix - Link system requirements to software requirements to associated design specifications and test protocols in one document (typically a spreadsheet). Include software hazards with software mitigations.

## Verification and Validation Requirements

Compliance with IEC 62304 requires verification and testing activities to be carried out by the manufacturer. At a general level, you need to establish a testing protocol that shows how design outputs meet design inputs. For software, your requirement specifications need to be verified in the testing process.(no content)Given that software requires updates over time, you will need to document ongoing testing to prove that you're maintaining compliance with IEC 62304. A traceability matrix is a useful tool that links together with your product design requirements, design specifications, and testing requirements.

## Coding Standards for Code Review

Coding standards are a crucial component of software acceptance criteria under the IEC 62304 standard. According to the guidance in Annex B.5.5, coding standards are used to specify a preferred coding style to consistently achieve desirable code characteristics. These standards can cover aspects such as understandability, language usage rules or restrictions, and complexity management.

## Risk Management Integration

Software Hazard Analysis - Create an IEC 62304 hazard analysis, identifying potential hazards and the software items that could cause them. Mitigations should feed back into the Requirements. Include OTS software hazard analysis and wireless QoS (if applicable).(no content)The ISO 14971 standard is required because it defines the framework for managing risks and identifying hazards. ISO 14971 provides a framework for performing your hazard analysis and risk assessment.

## Documentation Requirements

Documentation is a cornerstone of the IEC 62304 standard. Manufacturers must maintain comprehensive records of all software development activities, including design, testing, and validation.(no content)Note that each deliverable must be verified, and the plan should address how that is done (often review and sign-off).

## IEC 62304 Compliance Checklist Steps

Follow this step-by-step structure to ensure you tick off the main requirements of the standard: Define your software safety classification (A, B or C).(no content)Agile methods are hugely popular in modern software development, and they can be compatible with IEC 62304, as long as you maintain traceability, verification and the right levels of documentation.

## Integration with Quality Management Systems

Don't treat IEC 62304 as a standalone process. Your software lifecycle processes should be closely connected with your overall quality management system, especially if you're using ISO 13485. Align document formats (and some specific documents), as well as responsibilities and review cycles, across both standards.

This information provides a foundation for developing a comprehensive code review checklist that meets both FDA and IEC 62304 validation requirements for medical device software.

Based on my search, here's a comprehensive overview of IEC 62304 medical device software lifecycle requirements related to code review and traceability:

## IEC 62304 Overview

IEC 62304 â€“ medical device software â€“ software life cycle processes is an international standard published by the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC). The standard specifies life cycle requirements for the development of medical software and software within medical devices.(no content)It's a harmonized standard recognized by regulators like the U.S. FDA and European Commission under the Medical Device Regulation (MDR).

## Traceability Requirements

The standard mandates clear documentation of requirements, architecture, design, and verification activities, which in turn fosters transparency and traceability throughout the software development lifecycle.(no content)Clause 5 outlines the heart of IEC 62304: the structured software development process. It ensures that every function in medical device software is implemented with clear requirements, traceability, verification, and validation.

Key traceability elements include:

- Every requirement, design decision, and test must be traceable back to a specific risk. This creates an audit trail that can be used to justify design choices during regulatory reviews.

- IEC 62304 requires traceable control over software and artifacts. Clause 8 outlines the expectations for configuration management, a discipline that ensures the integrity, consistency, and traceability of software throughout its lifecycle.

## Code Review and Verification

Many manufacturers still use traceability systems which are manual, long, complex and, most of all, likely to be source of errors. Verification of software units can be done whether through unit, integration and system tests or through peer reviews.(no content)Coding standards are a key part of software acceptance criteria. Annex B.5.5 states: "To consistently achieve the desirable code characteristics, coding standards should be used to specify a preferred coding style. Examples of coding standards include requirements for understandability, language usage rules or restrictions, and complexity management."

## Safety Classification and Requirements

To tailor development rigor to risk, IEC 62304 requires software to be classified into one of three safety classes, A, B, or C, based on the potential harm it could cause if it fails.(no content)Safety Class A: No injury or damage to health is possible. Safety Class B: Non serious injury is possible. Safety Class C: Death or serious injury is possible.(no content)The higher the Safety classification of the medical device software, the more stringent the process requirements on such a medical device software. Class C Medical Software are required to comply with all the specifications in the standard, while Class B devices are exempt from some, and Class A are exempt from even more.

## Core Principles

The underlying principles of IEC 62304 are rigorous planning, thorough documentation, testing and verification of everything, and finally, traceability â€” a transparent mechanism to verify compliance of all parts of the standard.

## Documentation and Risk Management

Documentation is a cornerstone of the IEC 62304 standard. Manufacturers must maintain comprehensive records of all software development activities, including design, testing, and validation. The IEC 62304 checklist helps ensure that all necessary documentation is in place and traceable, providing evidence of compliance with the standard.(no content)As the software evolves, whether due to updates, bug fixes, or customer feedback, the risk file must be updated accordingly. Risk management is a living process. IEC 62304 doesn't allow teams to "fire and forget." Risk analysis must be woven into every change, enhancement, and release.

Here are the search results for "GAMP 5 software categories risk-based validation approach":

## GAMP 5 Software Categories and Risk-Based Validation Approach

### Overview of GAMP 5

The Good Automated Manufacturing Practice (GAMP 5Â®) guidelines define a set of core principles for GxP, as produced by the ISPE (International Society for Pharmaceutical Engineering).(no content)These guidelines are intended to ensure that pharmaceutical or medical device products are manufactured to the required quality, detailing a recognized standard for computer system validation (CSV) underpinned by a risk-based approach.(no content)GAMPÂ®5 provides a framework for the risk-based approach to computer system validation where a system is evaluated and assigned to a predefined category based on its intended use and complexity.

### Software Categories

GAMP 5 provides a risk-based approach to classifying software based on its impact on GxP and functional compliance. The main categories include:

- Category 1 â€“ infrastructure, Category 3 â€“ non-configurable, Category 4 â€“ configurable, Category 5 â€“ custom software.
- Category 2, associated with the firmware in GAMP 4, is removed from GAMP 5. The GAMP 5 categories defined in the 2nd edition are the same as its predecessor.(no content)The risk associated with each category increases sequentially from category 1 to 5. The more the risk associated with the category, the more rigorous Computer System Validation (CSV) approach is needed.(no content)Computerized systems are generally made up of a combination of components from different categories, and categories 3-5 should be viewed as a continuum.

### Risk-Based Approach Principles

The five main principles of GAMPÂ® 5's risk-based approach to compliance are: (1) To have a clear understanding of product and process; (2) To manage the system lifecycle using a quality management system; (3) To make these lifecycle activities scalable; (4) To verify that the approach to risk management is science-based; (5) To leverage supplier involvement throughout the system.(no content)Aside from being an excellent tool to help ensure regulatory compliance, GAMPÂ®5 is also useful when determining the scope of testing. The risk-based approach allows you to concentrate your testing efforts on the high-risk areas of the system while aiding in the formulation of a rationale for performing reduced testing on areas deemed low-risk.

### Validation by Category

- **Category 1 (Infrastructure)**: Since Category 1 software isn't configured for specific business processes, the validation approach is straightforward. The main goal is to ensure the integrity and reliability of the infrastructure itself. You're not testing business logic; you're confirming that the software is installed correctly and operates as the vendor intended.

- **Category 4 (Configurable)**: For a configured product (Category 4), requirements, functional and configuration testing is conducted to verify the requirements, functional and configuration specifications.(no content)A configurable ERP (Category 4) requires thorough testing of your specific settings.

- **Category 5 (Custom)**: A custom-built system (Category 5) demands a full lifecycle validation approach with extensive documentation.(no content)Higher-risk systems (e.g., custom code controlling product quality) warrant more rigorous testing and documentation, whereas low-risk infrastructure software may need only basic verification.

### GAMP 5 Second Edition (2022)

Maintaining the principles and framework of the first edition, ISPE GAMPÂ® 5: A Risk-Based Approach to Compliant GxP Computerized Systems (Second Edition) updates their application in the modern world including the increased importance of service providers, evolving approaches to software development, and expanded use of software tools and automation.(no content)Guidance on the application of new and developing technological areas such as artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), blockchain, cloud computing, and open-source software (OSS) has been included or updated. The importance of critical thinking and the application of patient-centric, risk-based approaches (aimed at quality and safety) versus primarily compliance-driven approaches is further underlined.

### Code Review in Validation

By focusing on risk, GAMP 5 helps avoid spending excessive time on documentation of inconsequential details, instead advocating "more testing over more documentation" for what truly matters. For example, rather than capturing voluminous screenshots for every test step, GAMP 5 suggests using exception-based recording (logging only deviations or unexpected outcomes) for routine tests.

For Category 5 custom software, code review typically forms part of the design specification verification and testing phases, aligned with the V-model lifecycle approach that GAMP 5 follows.

Based on my search, here's a comprehensive overview of FDA software validation traceability matrix requirements and documentation best practices:

## FDA Software Validation Traceability Matrix Requirements

### Regulatory Status

The United States Code of Federal Regulations does not specifically require a traceability matrix, but creating a traceability matrix is recognized as a validation best practice. However, traceability of user requirements in the validation of computerized systems is a regulatory expectation of the FDA as evidenced from their Guidance for Industry on the General Principles of Software Validation.(no content)An expectation of FDA is that you can provide proof of documented traceability analysis or a traceability matrix linking product design requirements, design specifications, risks, controls and tests.

### Purpose of the Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM)

The Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) is a document that links requirements throughout the validation process. The purpose of the Requirements Traceability Matrix is to ensure that all requirements defined for a system are tested in the test protocols. The traceability matrix is a tool both for the validation team, to ensure that requirements are not lost during the validation project, and for auditors, to review the validation documentation.(no content)The Requirements traceability matrix (RTM) is a key piece that establishes the system is fully implemented. The RTM documents each of the requirement tracing it to design, items, code, unit, integration and software system test. It is a simple and effective way for documenting your implementation in accord with the expectations of the FDA.

### Key Elements to Include

For FDA-regulated products, it is a key part of the Design History File (DHF), offering clear evidence of compliance with 21 CFR Part 820.(no content)Traceability in medical device development must be bidirectional, meaning every requirement should: Trace forward to design outputs and verification methods; Trace backward to its original source, such as a user need or risk control.(no content)A high-quality RTM includes both forward and backward traceability, often laid out like this: User Need â†’ System Requirement â†’ Design Input â†’ Design Output â†’ Verification Test â†’ Test Result; Hazard â†’ Risk Control â†’ Requirement â†’ Design Output â†’ Risk Verification.

### Regulatory Standards

The traceability matrix must align with applicable regulatory standards and guidelines governing medical devices, such as ISO 13485, FDA regulations (e.g., 21 CFR Part 820), and international standards (e.g., IEC 60601).(no content)You must also comply with IEC 62304, medical device software â€“ software lifecycle processes. This is required for CE Marking as a harmonized standard and recognized by the US FDA.

### Best Practices

Best practices, such as implementing a robust and comprehensive documentation process, using tools to manage and track relationships between artifacts, and regularly reviewing and updating traceability information, can help organizations avoid missed requirements, oversights, and other issues that can impact product quality and safety.(no content)Remember: if your team doesn't have a document to prove a test or action, those actions do not exist to the FDA and auditors.(no content)As a best practice, the V&V should be considered early in the design stage when developing requirement specifications for a product. Such an approach will help streamline the overall manufacturing and approval process.

### Risk Traceability

There should be harm identified for each software design requirement, or the traceability matrix should indicate that no harm can result from failure to meet the software design requirement. Next, the risk assessment should indicate what the risk controls are for each requirement identified with the potential for harm.(no content)ISO 14971:2019 mandates traceability between identified hazards, their mitigations, and verification activities. The RTM should show these connections clearly and concisely. This integration provides regulators with confidence that risks were identified, controlled, and validated.

### Types of Matrices

Depending on device complexity, multiple types of matrices may be maintained: User Needs Matrix: Links stakeholder needs to system-level requirements; Input-Output Matrix: Connects design inputs to corresponding outputs; Verification Matrix: Maps requirements to test protocols and results.(no content)Risk Matrix: Tracks hazards, control measures, and their validation status; Software RTM (as required by IEC 62304): Maps software requirements to units, code modules, and test cases.

### Maintaining the Matrix

This matrix should be a living document that is updated continuously as the project progresses and artifacts change.(no content)An RTM must evolve with the product. As requirements or design elements change, trace links must be reviewed and updated to stay accurate. Keeping the RTM current ensures compliance, avoids gaps, and supports smooth audits.

Based on the search results, I can now provide you with comprehensive information on FDA code review best practices for medical device software, including 21 CFR Part 11, Part 820, and peer review methodologies.

## FDA Code Review Best Practices for Medical Device Software

### Regulatory Framework

**21 CFR Part 820 (Quality System Regulation)**

21 CFR Part 820 outlines the current good manufacturing practice (CGMP) guidelines for developing medical devices. It governs the methods, facilities and controls used for medical device design, manufacture, packaging, labeling, storage, installation and service.(no content)21 CFR Part 820 establishes the basic requirements for manufacturers of finished medical devices. It is designed to ensure devices are safe and effective and comply with the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act).

**21 CFR Part 11 (Electronic Records; Electronic Signatures)**

Title 21 CFR Part 11 is the part of Title 21 of the Code of Federal Regulations that establishes the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulations on electronic records and electronic signatures (ERES). Part 11 defines the criteria under which electronic records and electronic signatures are considered trustworthy, reliable, and equivalent to paper records.(no content)21 CFR Parts 11 and 820 are separate but related FDA regulations that govern different aspects of the pharmaceutical, biotech and medical device industries to ensure the quality, safety, and effectiveness of medical products. Part 11 deals with electronic records and electronic signatures, and Part 820 deals with establishment of a quality management system.

### Code Review Requirements and Best Practices

**FDA Guidance on Code Reviews**

The IEC 62304 does not require explicit code reviews. But it does see code reviews as a way to test software units. However, written test criteria for code reviews must be available and the code review should be documented in writing as well.(no content)The FDA does not require code reviews, but writes the following in the Software Validation Guidance Document: "Source code should also be evaluated to verify its compliance with the corresponding detailed design specification. [...] Source code evaluations are often implemented as code inspections and code walkthroughs. Such static analyses provide a very effective means to detect errors before execution of the code. They allow for examination of each error in isolation and can also help in focusing later dynamic testing of the software. [...] Source code evaluations should be extended to verification of internal linkages between modules and layers (horizontal and vertical interfaces), and compliance with their design specifications."

**Defining Your Review Process**

The statutory requirement for reviews can be found in 21 CFR part 820. Here, too, no specific method is named. This, then, gives us the answer: You describe, as a manufacturer, in your 820-compliant quality management system, what kind of reviews you will make. And according to that, you need to document what people are involved - by signature.

### Peer Review Methodologies

**Peer-Reviewed Testing**

A formal test case review must be conducted and documented during the validation and verification stage. Any comments are documented in the validation and verification document following the peer review. This process ensures that the test case design and execution are undertaken with the highest level of quality and oversight.(no content)Code reviews are systematic evaluations of the code intended to find defects, improve code quality, and aid engineers in learning the source code that serves as quality assurance for the code base. To receive a second perspective on the code implementation and detect errors, logic issues, or uncover edge cases, this can be done by another developer or technical team lead.

**Integrated Development Practices**

An integrated SDLC merges validation and verification activities, including defect prevention practices such as unit testing, peer code reviews, static analysis, manual testing, and regression testing, throughout the SDLC. The result of such an approach is an emphasis on planning, verification, testing, traceability, and configuration management.(no content)Perform static (code review) and dynamic (functional) testing. Use peer reviews and checklists to catch errors early.

### Static Analysis and Independent Review

There is no independent review required for software used in medical devices, and the FDA historically has not had the bandwidth to assess the quality of the code directly.(no content)As part of its Infusion Pump Improvement Initiative, the FDA is encouraging manufacturers to use static code analysis. With static analysis, software problems are detected early in the device development process, and it is possible to examine all possible execution paths.(no content)The FDA is now making medical device software quality a top priority, recommending better software development practices, including static analysis tools, to help manufacturers eliminate software defects during development.

### Software Validation Requirements

**Part 11 Validation**

Section 11.10(a) Validation of systems: Requires that systems be validated to ensure accuracy, reliability, consistent intended performance, and ability to discern invalid or altered records. Validation should be performed for both closed and open systems that create, modify, maintain, archive, retrieve, or transmit electronic records subject to the regulation.(no content)Although persons must still comply with all applicable predicate rule requirements for validation (e.g., 21 CFR 820.70(i)), this guidance should not be read to impose any additional requirements for validation. We suggest that your decision to validate computerized systems, and the extent of the validation, take into account the impact the systems have on your ability to meet predicate rule requirements. You should also consider the impact those systems might have on the accuracy, reliability, integrity, availability, and authenticity of required records and signatures.

### Audit Trail and Documentation Requirements

The audit trail requirements in this section are similar to the document control requirements of 21 CFR Part 820. Medical device companies must maintain appropriate control over systems documentation, including revision and change control procedures to maintain an audit trail that documents changes in the system. An audit trail ensures that every activity which happens in the record-keeping system generates a record and can be reviewed later.

### Key Compliance Best Practices

Tracking and managing all changes to your code before and during the test process is integral to the success of your FDA compliance software. Having a proper source control platform means that developers can trace each test run on a certain date against the specific software requirements for those test cases.(no content)Validation must be established and re-established for even small changes. This means that validation activities, including static analysis, unit testing, code review, etc., must be repeated if the code has changed.(no content)Ensure that validation is performed by someone not involved in software development. For complex or high-risk products, consider third-party or external audits.

Based on my search, here's a comprehensive overview of Computer System Validation (CSV) training related to FDA 21 CFR Part 11 in the pharmaceutical industry:

## Computer System Validation (CSV) & FDA 21 CFR Part 11 Training

### What is CSV?

CSV is a documented process for assuring that a computer system does exactly what it is designed to do consistently and reproducibly. The process ensures that the system meets all predetermined requirements and is fit for its intended use.

### Key Regulatory Framework

The FDA regulations outline the requirements for CSV, including FDA 21 CFR Part 820.70, FDA 21 CFR Part 11.10, FDA 21 CFR Part 11, European Union Annex 11, FDA's Guidance Document about Software Validation, GMP Directives, ISO 13485, and Good Automated Manufacturing Practice (GAMP) 5.(no content)In the United States, the FDA defines requirements for electronic records and electronic signatures under 21 CFR Part 11. This regulation establishes the criteria by which electronic records are considered trustworthy, reliable, and equivalent to paper records.

### FDA Expectations for CSV

The FDA expects that all computer systems used in the design, manufacture, packaging, labeling, storage, installation, and servicing of all finished products intended for human use should comply with 21 CFR Part 11 and other relevant regulations.(no content)The FDA expects firms to maintain comprehensive documentation of the validation process, including validation plans, system specifications, test protocols, and test results. The documentation should be sufficient to demonstrate that the system is validated and operates correctly.

### Training Topics Typically Covered

Training courses typically cover current regulations (e.g., 21 CFR 820.70(i), 21 CFR Part 11, 21 CFR 211.68), standards (e.g., ISO 13485), guidance (e.g., FDA's General Principles of Software Validation, AAMI/ISO TIR80002-2), methods (e.g., V-model, Agile Scrum), and terminology governing the design, development, validation, release, and maintenance of regulated software systems.

### Best Practices for Compliance

To ensure success, life sciences organizations should adopt these strategies: Develop a Risk-Based Validation Plan focusing on systems that impact product quality and patient safety; Implement Robust Documentation maintaining traceable records including validation protocols, test scripts, and reports; Conduct IQ/OQ/PQ Testing to validate installation, operation, and performance of systems; Train Teams on Compliance Protocols ensuring staff understand CSV procedures and Part 11 requirements; and Monitor and Maintain Systems by regularly reviewing systems for compliance and revalidating after changes.

### FDA Guidance on Validation

The FDA suggests that decisions to validate computerized systems, and the extent of the validation, should take into account the impact the systems have on the ability to meet predicate rule requirements. Companies should also consider the impact those systems might have on the accuracy, reliability, integrity, availability, and authenticity of required records and signatures.

### Training Providers and Resources

Several organizations offer specialized CSV and 21 CFR Part 11 training, including:

- FDA Compliance Specialists, Inc., which provides Global GxP, Medical Device, 21 CFR Part 11, and Supplier Quality Auditing, Computer System Validation, Inspection Readiness, and FDA Compliance and Quality Training Services to pharmaceutical, medical device, and biotechnology industries.

- Computer system validation has been regulated by FDA for more than 40 years, as it relates to systems used in the manufacturing, testing and distribution of products in the pharmaceutical, biotechnology, medical device or other FDA-regulated industries.

### Emerging Trends

As digital transformation accelerates and the industry moves toward risk-based models such as Computer Software Assurance (CSA), CSV will continue to evolve.(no content)Training also covers current and future regulatory enforcement trends by the U.S. FDA and other global regulatory authorities, including the upcoming Computer Software Assurance Guidance from the U.S. FDA.

results:
Based on my search, here's a comprehensive overview of FDA clinical trial software, CTMS validation, 21 CFR Part 11, and warning letters:

## 21 CFR Part 11 and Clinical Trial Software

FDA 21 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 11 refers to the FDA's regulations on electronic records and electronic signatures for clinical trials.(no content)This regulation applies to all industries under FDA regulation, including pharmaceuticals, medical devices, biotechnology, and other life sciences. It outlines the criteria under which electronic records and electronic signatures are considered trustworthy, reliable, and equivalent to paper records and handwritten signatures.

## Systems That Require Compliance

Key systems requiring Part 11 compliance include Electronic Data Capture (EDC) systems used to collect clinical trial data, Clinical Trial Management Systems (CTMS) that help manage different stages of clinical trials, and Electronic Trial Master File (eTMF) systems that digitally store and manage critical clinical study documents.

## CTMS Validation Requirements

For Clinical Trial Management Systems (CTMS), compliance audits should review access controls, system logs and trails, data backup protocols, and system validation documentation.(no content)For customized systems or COTS systems integrated with other systems, sponsors should develop and document a validation plan, conduct the validation in accordance with the plan, and document the validation results.(no content)There is no certification process for Part 11, so any statement of compliance is just thatâ€”a statement, which isn't backed by any sort of third-party auditing body.

## FDA Warning Letters and Enforcement

The FDA issues warning letters to regulated organizations that are in violation of Part 11. A formal notice from the FDA indicates an organization is not in compliance with regulatory requirements, outlines the specific violations, and requires corrective actions within a set timeframe.(no content)In 2024, the FDA's Center for Devices and Radiological Health (CDRH) issued 529 warning letters, with 8% (44) directed at medical device manufacturers for issues including design validation failures and data integrity concerns.(no content)In November 2024, the FDA issued a Complete Response Letter to Applied Therapeutics, citing deficiencies in data integrity and protocol adherence, including violations of 21 CFR Part 11. As a result, their new drug application was not approved, and they are now facing shareholder lawsuits.

## Penalties for Non-Compliance

The FDA has the authority to impose significant penalties including import alerts preventing products from entering the US market, seizure of affected products, injunctions prohibiting further manufacturing until violations are corrected, civil monetary penalties in the millions of dollars, and consent decrees requiring expensive third-party oversight of remediation efforts.

## Key Compliance Requirements

There are four main pillars for FDA 21 CFR Part 11 compliance: system validation to prove your system works reliably, user access controls to restrict actions to authorized personnel, and audit trails to maintain secure, tamper-proof logs of all changes and approvals.(no content)Changes to data stored on electronic media will always require an audit trail in accordance with 21 CFR 11.10(e). Documentation should include who made the changes, when, and why they were made.

## Vendor and Sponsor Responsibilities

Under certain circumstances, FDA may choose to inspect electronic service vendors engaged in providing services regulated by FDA. For example, if required records are not available from the sponsor or clinical investigation site, FDA may choose to inspect records at the vendor's facilities.(no content)Many software vendors provide documentation and proof of testing to demonstrate their platform meets 21 CFR Part 11 technical requirements. Working with a software vendor that understands the regulations can reduce your testing burden, allowing you to adopt a risk-based approach and incorporate the vendor's test documentation into your computer system validation.
